Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative proposal: Developing a battery of methods for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of silver and gold nanomaterials in human cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Ioana Pavel Sizemore/Adam de la Zerda
Proposal Number: 1438340/1434465
Institution: Wright State University/Stanford University
Title: Collaborative proposal: Developing a battery of methods for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of silver and gold nanomaterials in human cells

The extensive use of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) in consumer products and industry and the use of many kinds of NPs in healthcare as diagnostic and therapeutic tools require an understanding of their potential toxicities. However, as observed by the National Nanotechnology Initiative, there are only a limited number of techniques that could expand our understanding of the mechanisms by which nanomaterials influence cell behavior. The main scientific goal of this project is to fill these knowledge gaps by developing a battery of tools for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of environmentally representative AgNPs and biomedically relevant gold nanorods (AuNRs) in human cells. Key parameters, which will be considered in order to test the efficiency and practicality of the proposed methods, will include nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time. The methods that are to be developed will be captured and shared through Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs). In addition, the knowledge gained from the proposed research will be used in setting up new course modules and will be disseminated into the broader community, e.g., through interactions with a local museum and development of two hour hands-on laboratory modules for over 100 K-6 through K-9 students.

A battery of interdisciplinary methods (ICP-OES/TFF, Raman-SERS/MatLab codes, and electron microscopy /bioassays) will be used for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of environmentally representative silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) and biomedically relevant gold nanoparticles (AuNRs) in human cells. Key parameters that will be considered to test the efficiency and practicality of the proposed methods will include nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time. To accomplish their goals, The PIs propose two specific aims. In Aim1, the PIs will characterize the physico-chemical properties of NPs, according to the U.S. EPA standards, before cellular exposure and then at various benchmark times during cellular trafficking. In Aim 2, using their suite of tools, the investigators will study the trafficking mechanisms of AgNPs and AuNRs in human cells as a function of nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:        This NSF-Award developed a battery of interdisciplinary methods for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of representative silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) and gold nanorods (AuNRs) in cells. These measurement tools will serve regulatory agencies and researchers by identifying the risk assessment and control associated with the heavy use of noble nanomaterials in consumer products and biomedical applications.

Intellectual Merit:       The newly developed analytical- and imaging-based methodologies were successfully tested in the identification of key pharmacokinetic parameters: the cellular Absorption (A), Distribuion (D), Metabolism (M), and Elimination (E) of spherical AgNPs (positively and negatively charged) and AuNRs (aspect ratios of 2-5). Several of these ADME methodologies were then translated from in vitro (animal and human kidney cells, human red blood cells (RBCs), cord and adult blood) to in vivo models (Sprague Dawley rats).

(A) Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and graphite furnace atomic absorption spectroscopy (GFAAS)-based methods were implemented in conjunction with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)-endorsed quality control methods for the low ppb quantification of the total amount of Ag or Au within whole cells or organelles. In kidney cells, both AgNPs+ and AgNPs- of 10 nm in diameter interacted with cells, but AgNPs+ exhibited a stronger (~25-fold) cellular affinity than AgNPs- at any exposure time or concentration. The absorption of AgNPs+ and AgNPs - followed zeroth- and first-order rate law, respectively, for the 300 μg mL-1 exposure in the 4-24 h time period. Furthermore, Ag accumulation increased with the increase in the AgNP exposure concentration (3-300 μg mL-1) and was significant above 100 μg mL-1. Among all examined cells, RBCs exhibited the highest Ag accumulation (48?5%). Thus, in spite of their negative charge and biocompatible citrate coating, AgNPs could remain concentrated in the circulatory system rather than being dispersed or excreted.

(D) CytoViva-based hyperspectral imaging (CHSI) and Raman-based hyperspectral imaging (RHSI) were adopted to image the internalization and cellular distribution of AgNPs/AuNRs in a label-free, non-invasive manner, and with minimum sample preparation. While CHSI confirmed their presence through the associated scattering signatures, RHSI revealed the biochemical nature of nanomaterials? surroundings and their covalent interactions with biomolecules. CHSI: In kidney cells, both AgNPs+ and AgNPs- entered the cells after 4 hours. Afterward, the increase in exposure time led to a wider distribution of AgNPs across the kidney cells with distinct patterns of cellular entry/exit and subcellular localization. In RBCs, a significant amount of the interacting AgNPs- (~70%) were found to be adherent to the cell membrane and cause structural damage. RHSI: In kidney cells, the chemometric analysis of hyperspectral Raman data indicated a larger accumulation of AgNPs+ at the plasma membrane when compared to AgNPs-. In RBCs, important changes in the spectral profile of hemoglobin and cellular membrane were noticed upon exposure to citrate-capped AgNPs when compared to controls, which was indicative of their strong interaction. Alarmingly, a decrease in oxygen binding to hemoglobin was signaled by diminished oxyhemoglobin and enhanced deoxyhemoglobin Raman marker bands.

(M) A remarkable nanotoxicity tool emerged from the combination of cloud point extraction with tangential flow filtration (CPE-TFF) for the effective isolation of AgNPs and Ag+ from colloidal and biological matrices, and for monitoring their cellular redox interconversion. The in vivo and in vitro toxicity of AgNPs has been largely related to the Ag+ released from AgNPs, and oxidative stress associated with both AgNPs and Ag+. In kidney cells, AgNPs+ were more cytotoxic than AgNPs-; the LC50 values in animal cells were 32 ? 2 and 125 ? 4 μg mL-1 of AgNPs+ and AgNPs-, respectively. Furthermore, human HEK293 cells were found to be more sensitive to AgNP- exposure than animal Vero 76 cells (LC50 = 26 ? 3 μg mL-1). Also, less or equal than 11?4% of the administered, sub-lethal AgNPs were oxidized to Ag+ within the cellular matrix. In addition to a decreased cell viability, the glutathione levels were also found to be significantly depleted in kidney cells. In RBCs, functionalization of AgNPs with biocompatible agents rendered them less toxic to K metabolism as demonstrated by GFAAS. No significant difference was observed on K metabolism upon exposure to AuNRs under similar conditions to AgNPs.

(E) CPE-TFF facilitated the isolation of the AgNPs and Ag+ cleared by cells, while ICP-OES quantified these amounts for mass balance assessments. In kidney cells, AgNPs- were cleared through first-order kinetics probably via exocytosis, while AgNPs+ followed zeroth-order kinetics.

Broader Impacts:         This NSF-Award resulted in the publication of 7 research manuscripts and over 50 conference presentations. It also facilitated the completion of 5 Ph.D., 19 M.S., and 7 undergraduate research projects. A Web site, https://github.com/dpfoose/Vespucci, was created to describe the new, cross-platform software tool, Vespucci, and its capabilities for the multivariate analysis of hyperspectral Raman data. Furthermore, over 150 students were offered annually a hands-on, education module that was highly ranked in the anonymous evaluations.
